dialogs.original: What a plague means my niece, to take the death of her brother thus? I am sure cares an enemy to life.
dialogs.translated: What is ailing my niece, that she reacts so strongly to her brother's death? I'm now sure that caring too much is bad for one's health.

dialogs.original: By my troth, Sir Toby, you must come in earlier o' nights. Your cousin, my lady, takes great exceptions to your ill hours.
dialogs.translated: By God, Sir Toby, you must come home earlier at night. Your niece, my lady, strongly disapproves of the late hours you keep.

dialogs.original: Why, let her except, before excepted.
dialogs.translated: Well, let her disapprove of meI disapprove of her.

dialogs.original: Ay, but you must confine yourself within the modest limits of order.
dialogs.translated: Yes, but you must at least confine yourself within the limits of order and decency.

dialogs.original: Confine? Ill confine myself no finer than I am.   These clothes are good enough to drink in, and so be these boots too.   An they be not, let them hang themselves in their own straps.
dialogs.translated: Confine myself? I'll only confine myself to these clothes I'm wearing. They're good enough to drink in, and these boots are too. And if they aren't, then let them hang themselves by their own straps.

dialogs.original: That quaffing and drinking will undo you:   I heard my lady talk of it yesterday, and of a foolish knight that you brought in one night here to be her wooer.
dialogs.translated: All this drinking will be your ruin: I heard my lady Olivia talking about it yesterday. She also spoke of some foolish knight you brought here one night to woo her.

dialogs.original: Who, Sir Andrew Aguecheek?
dialogs.translated: Who, Sir Andrew Aguecheek?

dialogs.original: Ay, he.
dialogs.translated: Yes, him.

dialogs.original: Hes as tall a man as anys in Illyria.
dialogs.translated: He's as tall and brave as any man in Illyria.

dialogs.original: Whats that to the purpose?
dialogs.translated: What does that have to do with anything?

dialogs.original: Why, he has three thousand ducats a year.
dialogs.translated: Well, he has an income of three thousand ducats a year.

dialogs.original: Ay, but hell have but a year in all these ducats. Hesa very fool and a prodigal.
dialogs.translated: Yes, but he'll only make all those ducats last for one year. He's foolish, wasteful, and reckless.

dialogs.original: Fie, that youll say so! He plays o' the viol-de-gamboys,   and speaks three or four languages wordfor word without book,   and hath all the good gifts of nature.
dialogs.translated: How dare you say so! He plays the violin, and speaks three or four languages word for word from memory. He has all of nature's good gifts.

dialogs.original: He hath indeed, almost natural,   for besides that hes afool, hes a great quarreler,   and but that he hath the gift of a coward to allay the gust he hath in quarreling,   tis thought among the prudent he would quickly have the gift of a grave.
dialogs.translated: He does indeed seem like a natural-born fooland besides being a fool, he's argumentative. If he didn't have the coward's gift of stepping away from a fight, they say he would've been long dead by now.

dialogs.original: By this hand, they are scoundrels and substractors thatsay so of him. Who are they?
dialogs.translated: By God, anyone who says that about him is a villain and a naysayer. Who said that?

dialogs.original: They that add, moreover, hes drunk nightly in your company.
dialogs.translated: They also say that he gets drunk with you every night.

dialogs.original: With drinking healths to my niece. Ill drink to her aslong as there is a passage in my throat and drink in Illyria.   Hes a coward and a coistrel that will not drink to my niece till his brains turn o' th' toe like aparish top.   What, wench!    Castiliano vulgo    , for here comes Sir Andrew Agueface.
dialogs.translated: We are only toasting my niece when we drink. I'll drink to her as long as there's a hole in my throat and alcohol in Illyria. Only cowards and scum wouldn't drink to my niece until their brains spin round like a top. What do you have to say to that! But hush, we must be polite. Here comes Sir Andrew Agueface himself.

dialogs.original: Sir Toby Belch! How now, Sir Toby Belch!
dialogs.translated: Sir Toby Belch! How are you, Sir Toby Belch?

dialogs.original: Sweet Sir Andrew!
dialogs.translated: Sweet Sir Andrew.

dialogs.original: [To MARIA]  Bless you, fair shrew.
dialogs.translated: [To MARIA] And hello to you, pretty wench.

dialogs.original: And you too, sir.
dialogs.translated: Hello to you, sir.

dialogs.original: Accost, Sir Andrew, accost.
dialogs.translated: Accost her, Sir Andrew, accost her.

dialogs.original: Whats that?
dialogs.translated: What's that?

dialogs.original: My nieces chambermaid.
dialogs.translated: This is my niece's chambermaid.

dialogs.original: Good Mistress Accost, I desire better acquaintance.
dialogs.translated: Good Miss Accost-her, I look forward to knowing you better.

dialogs.original: My name is Mary, sir.
dialogs.translated: My name is Mary, sir.

dialogs.original: Good Mistress Mary Accost
dialogs.translated: Good Miss Mary Accost-her

dialogs.original: You mistake, knight. Accost is front her, board her, woo her, assail her.
dialogs.translated: You're mistaken, knight. "Accost her" isn't her nameI meant that you should face her, greet her, woo her, and conquer her.

dialogs.original: By my troth, I would not undertake her in this company.Is that the meaning of accost?
dialogs.translated: I say, I wouldn't do that in this company. Is that really what you meant by "accost her?"

dialogs.original: Fare you well, gentlemen.  [she starts to exit]
dialogs.translated: Goodbye, gentlemen. [She starts to exit]

dialogs.original: An thou let part so, Sir Andrew, would thou mightst never draw sword again.
dialogs.translated: If you let her leave like that, Sir Andrew, you don't deserve to ever draw your sword again.

dialogs.original: An you part so, mistress, I would I might never draw sword again. Fair lady, do you think you have fools in hand?
dialogs.translated: If you leave like this, miss, I swear I won't ever draw my sword again. Why are you leaving, fair ladydo you think you have fools on your hands here?

dialogs.original: Sir, I have not you by the hand.
dialogs.translated: Sir, I'm not holding your hand.

dialogs.original: Marry, but you shall have, and heres my hand.  [he offers her his hand]
dialogs.translated: Indeed, but you will be, and here's my hand. [He offers her his hand]

dialogs.original: [taking his hand]   Now, sir, thought is free.   I pray you, bring your hand to the buttery-bar and let it drink.
dialogs.translated: [Taking his hand] Now, sir, everyone has a right to their opinions. Please, take your hand to the dairy and let it drink.

dialogs.original: Wherefore, sweetheart? Whats your metaphor?
dialogs.translated: What do you mean, sweetheart? Is this a metaphor?

dialogs.original: Its dry, sir.
dialogs.translated: A dry one, sir.

dialogs.original: Why, I think so. I am not such an ass, but I can keep my hand dry. But whats your jest?
dialogs.translated: Well, I should hope so. I'm not such a fool that I can't keep my hand dry. But what's the joke?

dialogs.original: A dry jest, sir.
dialogs.translated: Just some dry humor, sir.

dialogs.original: Are you full of them?
dialogs.translated: Are you full of such jokes?

dialogs.original: Ay, sir, I have them at my fingers' ends. Marry, now I let go your hand, I am barren.
dialogs.translated: Yes, sir, I have a handful of them. Although now that I've let go of your hand, I've lost the biggest joke I had.

dialogs.original: O knight, thou lackest a cup of canary. When did I see thee so put down?
dialogs.translated: Oh knight, you need some wine. Have you ever been put down like that before?

dialogs.original: Never in your life, I think, unless you see canary putme down.   Methinks sometimes I have no more wit than a Christian or an ordinary man has.   But I am a great eaterof beef, and I believe that does harm to my wit.
dialogs.translated: Never, I think, except when I've been put down by too much wine. Sometimes I think I'm no smarter than a humble, ordinary man. But I eat a lot of beef, and maybe that hurts my intelligence.

dialogs.original: No question.
dialogs.translated: There's no question about that.

dialogs.original: An I thought that, Id forswear it. Ill ride home tomorrow,Sir Toby.
dialogs.translated: If I really thought that, I'd give up beef altogether. I think I'll ride home tomorrow, Sir Toby.

dialogs.original: Pourquoi,  my dear knight?
dialogs.translated: Pourquoi, my dear knight?

dialogs.original: What is pourquoi? Do, or not do?   I would I had bestowed that time in the tongues that I have in fencing, dancing, and bear-baiting. O, had I but followed the arts!
dialogs.translated: What does "pourquoi" mean? Does it mean to do or not do? I wish I had spent more time learning languages instead of fencing, dancing, and bear-baiting. Oh, if I'd only studied more!

dialogs.original: Then hadst thou had an excellent head of hair.
dialogs.translated: Then you would have an excellent head of hair.

dialogs.original: Why, would that have mended my hair?
dialogs.translated: Why, would that have improved my hair?

dialogs.original: Past question, for thou seest it will not curl by nature.
dialogs.translated: Certainly, for you can see that it won't curl naturally.

dialogs.original: But it becomes me well enough, does t not?
dialogs.translated: But my hair still suits me well enough, doesn't it?

dialogs.original: Excellent. It hangs like flax on a distaff.   And I hopeto see a housewife take thee between her legs and spin it off.
dialogs.translated: It looks excellent. It hangs like flax waiting to be spun. And I hope to see some hussy take it between her legs and spin it off with a venereal disease.

dialogs.original: Faith, Ill home tomorrow, Sir Toby. Your niece will not be seen.   Or if she be, its four to one shell none of me.   The count himself here hard by woos her.
dialogs.translated: Truly, I'm going home tomorrow, Sir Toby. Your niece refuses to see anyone. Even if she did see me, chances are she'd reject me. The duke himself is courting her nearby.

dialogs.original: Shell none o' the count.   Shell not match above her degree, neither in estate, years, nor wit. I have heard her swear t   . Tut, theres life in t, man.
dialogs.translated: She'll reject the duke. She won't marry anyone who's above her social rank, her wealth, her age, or her intelligenceI've heard her swear this. So cheer up, you're still in the running, man.

dialogs.original: Ill stay a month longer.   I am a fellow o' th' strangest mind i' th' world. I delight in masques and revels sometimes altogether.
dialogs.translated: I'll stay a month longer then. I must be the strangest fellow on earth. Sometimes my greatest pleasures are masquerades, plays, and dancing.

dialogs.original: Art thou good at these kickshawses, knight?
dialogs.translated: Are you good at such trifles, knight?

dialogs.original: As any man in Illyria, whatsoever he be, under the degree of my betters.   And yet I will not compare with anold man.
dialogs.translated: As good as any man in Illyria, as long as he isn't better than I am. And yet I'm not as good as an experienced dancer.

dialogs.original: What is thy excellence in a galliard, knight?
dialogs.translated: How good are you at the fast dances, knight?

dialogs.original: Faith, I can cut a caper.
dialogs.translated: Well, I can cut a caper.

dialogs.original: And I can cut the mutton to t.
dialogs.translated: And I can cut the meat to go with your capers.

dialogs.original: And I think I have the back-trick simply as strong as any man in Illyria.
dialogs.translated: And I think I can do that tricky backward step as well as any man in Illyria.

dialogs.original: Wherefore are these things hid? Wherefore have these gifts a curtain before 'em? Are they like to take dust, like Mistress Malls picture?   Why dost thou not go to church in a galliard and come home in a coranto?   My verywalk should be a jig. I would not so much as make waterbut in a sink-a-pace.   What dost thou mean? Is it a world to hide virtues in?   I did think, by the excellent constitution of thy leg, it was formed under the star ofa galliard.
dialogs.translated: Why do you keep these things hidden? Why do you keep your gifts behind a curtain? Are you afraid they'll get dusty, like some woman's portrait? Why don't you show off your skill by going to church dancing a galliard and coming home dancing a coranto? If I were you, even my walk would be a dance. I wouldn't even pee unless I was dancing at the same time. What do you mean by this? Is this a world where we should hide our virtues? I could always tell from your excellent legs that you were born under a dancing star.

dialogs.original: Ay, tis strong, and it does indifferent well in a dun-colored stock. Shall we set about some revels?
dialogs.translated: Yes, my legs are strong, and they don't look bad in brown stockings. Should we have a little dance?

dialogs.original: What shall we do else? Were we not born under Taurus?
dialogs.translated: What else are we going to do? Weren't we born under the sign of Taurus?

dialogs.original: Taurus! Thats sides and heart.
dialogs.translated: Taurus! But that governs the torso and the heart.

dialogs.original: No, sir, it is legs and thighs. Let me see the caper.  [SIRANDREW dances]  Ha, higher! Ha, ha, excellent!
dialogs.translated: No, sir, it governs the legs and the thighs. Let me see you dance. Ha, higher! Ha ha, excellent!
